workflow.name: Secure web form to Odoo CRM lead creation with UTM tracking
workflow.description:
# Web-to-Odoo Lead Funnel (UTM-ready)

Create `crm.lead` records in Odoo from any webform via a secure webhook.  
The workflow validates required fields, resolves UTMs **by name** (source, medium, campaign) and writes standard lead fields in Odoo. Clean, portable, and production-ready.

## Key features
- ‚úÖ **Secure Webhook** with Header Auth (`x-webhook-token`)
- ‚úÖ **Required fields validation** (`firstname`, `lastname`, `email`)
- ‚úÖ **UTM lookup by name** (`utm.source`, `utm.medium`, `utm.campaign`)
- ‚úÖ **Clean consolidation** before create (`name`, `contact_name`, `email_from`, `phone`, `description`, `type`, UTM IDs)
- ‚úÖ **Clear HTTP responses**: `200` success / `400` bad request

## Prerequisites
- Odoo with **Leads** enabled (CRM ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Leads)
- **Odoo API Key** for your user (use it as the password)
- n8n **Odoo credentials**: URL, DB name, Login, API Key
- **Public URL** for the webhook (ngrok/Cloudflare/reverse proxy). Ensure `WEBHOOK_URL` / `N8N_HOST` / `N8N_PROTOCOL` / `N8N_PORT` are consistent
- **Header Auth secret** (e.g., `x-webhook-token: <your-secret>`)

## How it works
1. **Ingest** ‚Äì The Webhook receives a POST at `/webhook(-test)/lead-webform` with Header Auth.  
2. **Validate** ‚Äì An IF node checks required fields; if missing ‚Üí respond with `400 Bad Request`.  
3. **UTM lookup** ‚Äì Three Odoo `getAll` queries fetch IDs by `name`:
   - `utm.source` ‚Üí `source_id`
   - `utm.medium` ‚Üí `medium_id`
   - `utm.campaign` ‚Üí `campaign_id`  
   If a record is not found, the corresponding ID remains `null`.
4. **Consolidate** ‚Äì Merge + Code nodes produce a single clean object:  
   `{ name, contact_name, email_from, phone, description, type: "lead", campaign_id, source_id, medium_id }`
5. **Create in Odoo** ‚Äì Odoo node (`crm.lead ‚Üí create`) writes the lead with standard fields + UTM Many2one IDs.
6. **Respond** ‚Äì Success node returns `200` with `{ status: "ok", lead_id }`.

## Payload (JSON)
**Required:** `firstname`, `lastname`, `email`  
**Optional:** `phone`, `notes`, `source`, `medium`, `campaign`

```json
{
  "firstname": "John",
  "lastname": "Doe",
  "email": "john.doe@example.com",
  "phone": "+393331234567",
  "notes": "Wants a demo",
  "source": "Ads",
  "medium": "Website",
  "campaign": "Spring 2025"
}
```

## Quick test
```bash
curl -X POST "https://<host>/webhook-test/lead-webform" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "x-webhook-token: <secret>" \
  -d '{"firstname":"John","lastname":"Doe","email":"john@ex.com",
       "phone":"+39333...", "notes":"Demo",
       "source":"Ads","medium":"Website","campaign":"Spring 2025"}'
```

## Notes
- Recent Odoo versions do not use the `mobile` field on leads/partners: use `phone` instead.
- Keep **secrets and credentials** out of the template; the user will set their own after import.
- If you want to **auto-create** missing UTM records, add an IF after each `getAll` and a `create` on `utm.*`.

workflow.name: Send Lead from Web to Odoo

parameters.content:
## Odoo - Lead Create 
Preparation of the request creating the right body for Lead custom object

## Webhook linked to different sources 
Example:
{
    "firstname" : "John",
    "lastname" : "Doe",
    "phone" : "+393331212123",
    "email" : "test@outlook.com",
    "source" : "Ads",
    "medium" : "Website",
    "notes" : "test notes",
    "campaign" : "WebMassive"
}

## How To Use

### Prerequisites
- **Odoo**: enable Leads (CRM ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Leads).
- **Odoo API Key** for your user (use it as the *password*).
- **n8n Odoo credentials**: URL, DB name, Login, **API Key**.
- **Public URL** for the webhook (ngrok/Cloudflare/reverse proxy). Make sure WEBHOOK_URL / N8N_HOST / N8N_PROTOCOL / N8N_PORT are consistent.
- **Header Auth**: set a secret, e.g. header `x-webhook-token: {{$env.WEBHOOK_SECRET}}`.

### Payload (JSON)
- **Required**: `firstname`, `lastname`, `email`
- **Optional**: `phone`, `notes`, `source`, `medium`, `campaign`

### Endpoints
- **Test**: `/webhook-test/lead-webform`
- **Prod**: `/webhook/lead-webform`

### Quick test
curl -X POST "https://<host>/webhook-test/lead-webform" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "x-webhook-token: <secret>" \
  -d '{"firstname":"John","lastname":"Doe","email":"john@ex.com",
       "phone":"+39333...", "notes":"Demo",
       "source":"Ads","medium":"Website","campaign":"Spring 2025"}'

parameters.jsCode:
const f = items[0]?.json;
return [{ json: { source_id: f?.id ?? null } }];

const f = items[0]?.json;
return [{ json: { medium_id: f?.id ?? null } }];

const f = items[0]?.json;
return [{ json: { campaign_id: f?.id ?? null } }];

parameters.content:
## How it works

1) **Ingest**
   - Webhook receives POST at the path above.
   - Header Auth is required (`x-webhook-token`).

2) **Validate**
   - IF node checks required fields; if any is missing ‚Üí Respond **400 Bad Request**.

3) **UTM lookup**
   - Three Odoo `getAll` nodes fetch IDs by name:
     - `utm.source` ‚Üí `source_id`
     - `utm.medium` ‚Üí `medium_id`
     - `utm.campaign` ‚Üí `campaign_id`
   - If not found, the ID remains `null` (safe default).

4) **Consolidate**
   - **Merge (append)** feeds a **Code** node that merges the 4 inputs into one clean object:
     `{ name, contact_name, email_from, phone, description, type: "lead",
        campaign_id, source_id, medium_id }`

5) **Create in Odoo**
   - Odoo node (`crm.lead ‚Üí create`) writes the lead using standard fields.

6) **Respond**
   - **Success 200** ‚Üí `{ "status": "ok", "lead_id": <id> }`
   - **Bad Request 400** with a clear error message when validation fails.

**Notes**
- Recent Odoo versions don‚Äôt have `mobile`: use **`phone`**.
- Keep credentials out of the template; users will select theirs after import.
- If you later want to auto-create missing UTM records, add an IF after each `getAll` and a `create` on `utm.*`.

user.name: Gaetano Castaldo
user.bio: With more than 15 years of experience as a technical and solution consultant, I have collaborated with major global companies in the manufacturing sector, such as logistics, automotive, electronics, travel, consumer goods, luxury, and fashion. I was also responsible for large innovative digital transformation programs implemented through the Salesforce ecosystem. I am passionate about delivering quality solutions that meet the needs and expectations of my clients.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
